G.L. c. 185C, \u00a7 3.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to G.L. c. 185C, § 3, as it involves a dispute between a residential tenant and a landlord.

G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, the covenant of quiet enjoyment is implied in every residential lease agreement, pursuant to G.L. c. 186, § 14.

Dartmouth v. Silva, 325 Mass. 401 (1950).proposition: Under Massachusetts law, the covenant of quiet enjoyment is implied in every residential lease agreement, pursuant to G.L. c. 186, § 14.
Dartmouth v. Silva, 325 Mass. 401 (1950).support_reasoning: The opinion concerns a town’s suit to abate a public nuisance caused by obstruction and diversion of a natural watercourse; it does not involve landlord-tenant law, leases, or covenants of quiet enjoyment. There is no discussion of G.L. c. 186, § 14, implied lease covenants, or any residential tenancy issues. Therefore, it cannot be cited as authority for an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment in residential leases under Massachusetts law.
Dartmouth v. Silva, 325 Mass. 401 (1950).relevant_excerpt: The plaintiff grounds its right to relief on the existence of a nuisance. We construe the findings of the master as establishing that the brook which ran through the land of the defendants was a natural watercourse. The obstruction of a watercourse so as to cause the water to flow over a highway is a public nuisance. Commonwealth v. Stevens, 10 Pick. 247. Commonwealth v. Fisher, 6 Met. 433, 437. New Salem v. Eagle Mill Co. 138 Mass. 8.

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).proposition: Defendant's actions and inactions constitute an ongoing breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment, as Defendant’s refusal to remedy the water intrusion has substantially interfered with Plaintiff's comfortable and peaceful enjoyment of the Premises.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).support_reasoning: The opinion squarely holds that the landlord’s failure to prevent repeated, unsanitary flooding in the tenant’s apartment constituted an interference with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, §14, based on an ongoing omission to remedy a defective, porous wall and associated water intrusion. The court explains that quiet enjoyment encompasses freedom from serious interferences that impair the character and value of the premises, and explicitly concludes that Gem’s failure to maintain sanitary, watertight conditions, allowing repeated flooding to continue, made it liable for interfering with Solomon’s quiet enjoyment. This directly supports the proposition that a landlord’s ongoing refusal to remedy water intrusion can amount to a continuing breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).relevant_excerpt: “The common law background of § 14 also suggests that malicious intent is not a condition of liability. The phrase ‘quiet enjoyment’ is a familiar term in landlord-tenant law, signifying the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interferences with his tenancy — acts or omissions that ‘impair the character and value of the leased premises.’ … Finally, Gem is liable to Solomon under § 14 because it violated its underlying duty to maintain sanitary conditions in her apartment, and thereby permitted repeated flooding to occur that interfered with her quiet enjoyment of her apartment.”

Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.proposition: Defendant's actions and inactions constitute an ongoing breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment, as Defendant’s refusal to remedy the water intrusion has substantially interfered with Plaintiff's comfortable and peaceful enjoyment of the Premises.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.support_reasoning: The case squarely holds that a landlord breaches the implied covenant of quiet enjoyment where conditions that substantially interfere with tenants’ use and enjoyment are the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did or failed to do, and the landlord had the ability to correct them but did not. The court emphasizes that the landlord’s conduct (including inaction and failure to abate a known, ongoing problem) is sufficient, even without an intent to evict, and treats the resulting substantial deprivation as a constructive eviction. By analogy, a landlord’s refusal to remedy serious water intrusion that substantially interferes with peaceful enjoyment would fall within this principle.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.relevant_excerpt: There are occasions, however, where a landlord has not intended to violate a tenant’s rights, but there was nevertheless a breach of the landlord’s covenant of quiet enjoyment which flowed as the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done... Although some of our opinions have spoken of particular action or inaction by a landlord as showing a presumed intention to evict, the landlord’s conduct, and not his intentions, is controlling.

Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.raw_text: Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273 (1994)
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, the covenant of quiet enjoyment is implied in every residential lease agreement, pursuant to G.L. c. 186, § 14.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.support_reasoning: The opinion does not explicitly say that the covenant of quiet enjoyment is implied in every residential lease pursuant to G.L. c. 186, § 14, but it clearly treats § 14 as the governing "quiet enjoyment" provision applicable to residential landlords and tenants and analyzes a public housing authority’s liability under it. Massachusetts cases generally recognize that this statutory covenant is read into residential tenancies. By relying on § 14 as the source of tenants’ quiet enjoyment rights in this context, the case provides supportive (though not explicit) authority for the proposition.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.relevant_excerpt:
General Laws c. 186, § 14, provides, in relevant part, that “any lessor or landlord who directly or indirectly interferes with the quiet enjoyment of any residential premises by the occupant” shall be punished by a fine or imprisonment, and also shall be subject to liability to the tenant for damages arising from the interference. This section also confers on the Superior and District Courts the authority in equity to restrain violations of its provisions. Id.

The covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant’s right to freedom from serious interference with his tenancy — acts or omissions that impair the character and value of the leasehold.

Druker v. Roland Wm. Jutras Assoc., Inc..raw_text: Druker v. Roland Wm. Jutras Assoc., Inc., 370 Mass. 383 (1976)
Druker v. Roland Wm. Jutras Assoc., Inc..proposition: G.L. c. 186, § 14 provides, in relevant part, that any lessor or landlord who directly or indirectly interferes with a tenant’s quiet enjoyment of their rented premises shall be liable for damages or three months’ rent, whichever is greater, as well as costs and attorneys’ fees.
Druker v. Roland Wm. Jutras Assoc., Inc..case_name: Druker v. Roland Wm. Jutras Associates, Inc.
Druker v. Roland Wm. Jutras Assoc., Inc..support_reasoning: The opinion in Druker v. Roland Wm. Jutras Assoc., Inc. does not discuss landlord-tenant law, G.L. c. 186, § 14, quiet enjoyment, statutory damages, or attorneys’ fees. It concerns contract-based claims and the implied covenant of good faith and fair dealing in the context of interior design services and alleged misuse of a restaurant concept. Therefore, it does not provide authority for the quoted proposition about G.L. c. 186, § 14.
Druker v. Roland Wm. Jutras Assoc., Inc..relevant_excerpt: We think the complaint sufficiently invokes the principle that “in every contract there is an implied covenant that neither party shall do anything which will have the effect of destroying or injuring the right of the other party to receive the fruits of the contract, which means that in every contract there exists an implied covenant of good faith and fair dealing.” Uproar Co. v. National Broadcasting Co., 81 F.2d 373, 377 (1st Cir.), cert. denied, 298 U.S. 670 (1936), quoting from Kirke La Shelle Co. v. Paul Armstrong Co., 263 N.Y. 79, 87 (1933).

Haddad v. Gonzalez, 410 Mass. 855 (1991).proposition: Despite receiving numerous complaints from Plaintiff about the water intrusion, Defendant dismissed the issue as a “minor cosmetic issue” and failed to take any meaningful action to remedy the leak.
Haddad v. Gonzalez, 410 Mass. 855 (1991).support_reasoning: The opinion discusses numerous habitability defects (heat, windows, flooring, infestation, etc.) and the landlord’s general failure to repair, but it does not mention water intrusion, leaks, or the landlord characterizing any issue as a “minor cosmetic issue.” Nor does it describe a pattern of complaints specifically about water intrusion that were dismissed in that manner. Therefore, this case does not support the specific factual proposition claimed.
Haddad v. Gonzalez, 410 Mass. 855 (1991).relevant_excerpt: After his view, the judge made express findings. Among other defects, the judge found that: (1) there was no functioning heating system; (2) several basement windows were missing; (3) the apartment windows were in deplorable condition and without screens; (4) ceiling fixtures were missing; (5) the walls and ceilings were cracked and had holes; (6) doors were missing knobs; (7) the flooring in places was hazardous; and (8) the apartment was infested with cockroaches and rodents.

Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.raw_text: Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184 (1973)
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.proposition: Defendant’s inaction and refusal to repair the defect have effectively deprived Plaintiff of the full use and enjoyment of the Premises.
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.support_reasoning: The excerpt focuses on whether landlords have an implied obligation (via statute or implied warranty) to maintain premises in habitable condition and on the interdependence of rent and repair obligations. It does not address a factual finding that the landlord’s inaction and refusal to repair have deprived a tenant of the full use and enjoyment of the premises, nor does it discuss constructive eviction or similar deprivation language. Thus it does not provide authority for the specific proposition stated.
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.relevant_excerpt: "The situation before us is that tenants who have admittedly withheld payment of rent for apartments which they continued to occupy despite alleged violations of the Code now take the position that by reason of the violations the landlord may neither evict them nor recover any rent from them. The opinion of the court holds that the tenants are subject to eviction because of their failure to pay rent, but that their liability for unpaid rent is limited to the reasonable value, if any, of their apartments, considering the alleged violations of the Code."

Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).proposition: Plaintiff has experienced headaches, which she believes are caused by mold resulting from the water damage.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).support_reasoning: The opinion concerns liability under the Massachusetts lead paint statute and the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment. It does not mention mold, water damage, headaches, or any similar physical symptoms; the injuries discussed are lead poisoning of children from lead paint. Therefore, this case does not provide authority for a proposition about a plaintiff’s headaches allegedly caused by mold from water damage.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).relevant_excerpt: In August, 1989, it was discovered that the two children suffered from lead poisoning, and a subsequent inspection by the department of health and hospitals of Cambridge revealed that there was a dangerous level of lead in the apartment. After notifying the landlords, the Al-Ziab family moved out of the apartment temporarily, while the landlords arranged for removal of the lead paint by a professional.

Winchester v. O\u2019Brien, 266 Mass. 33.proposition: Defendant’s breach has directly caused Plaintiff economic loss and substantial annoyance, including damage to her personal property, physical discomfort, and significant disruption to her ability to use and occupy the Premises.
Winchester v. O\u2019Brien, 266 Mass. 33.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely finds that the landlord’s remodeling activities, undertaken in connection with the leased premises, caused the tenant economic loss (loss of business income and damage to property) and significant interference with use and enjoyment, including discomfort and disruption of his dental practice. The court affirms a damages award based on property damage and lost business income arising directly from the landlord’s acts that made access difficult, created noise, dirt, dust, dampness, and interruptions of utilities, thereby substantially impairing the tenant’s beneficial enjoyment. This aligns closely with the proposition that defendant’s breach directly caused economic loss, property damage, physical discomfort, and substantial disruption of use and occupancy.
Winchester v. O\u2019Brien, 266 Mass. 33.relevant_excerpt: “Even though the work was carried on in a reasonable and proper manner and entirely outside the rooms leased, injury was done to the property and appliances used in those rooms; there were interruptions of the electric and water service therein, the plaintiff’s right of access was made more difficult, his property was injured, and he suffered a loss of income in business. … It is evident from the facts found that there has been a substantial and continued interference with the plaintiff’s beneficial enjoyment of the leased premises….”
